channel.title: Help fixing this error
channel.description: src\server\mysql\impl\Highscores.java:4: error: cannot find symbol import server.mysql.Database; ^ symbol: class Database location: package server.mysql src\server\mysql\impl\Highscores.java:22: error: cannot find symbol Database db = new Database("212.1.208.6", "technoxp_hs", "highscores", "technoxp_hs"); ^ symbol: class Database location: class Highscores src\server\mysql\impl\Highscores.java:22: error: cannot find symbol Database db = new Database("212.1.208.6", "technoxp_hs", "highscores", "technoxp_hs"); ^ symbol: class Database location: class Highscores 3 errors Press any key to continue . . .

item.title: Help fixing this error
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Again, I need to see the ENTIRE MySQL statement.

What you just gave me is an exact copy of the error you sent in the picture, but this time in text. Please re-read what I said, and try again.

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:4, topic:550996”]It says your SQL syntax is off.
Meaning you’re trying to submit data to the SQL table, but it’s not in the right format. It’s probably missing some single quotes around some text. I can’t be 100% certain as that doesn’t show the entire sql statement…

If you could use system.out.println to print the sql statement, then right click the console and hit mark you will be able to select the text in the console. Select the entire SQL statement, and then hit enter. That will copy it to your clipboard.
Paste that here so I can see the SQL statement.[/quote]

Read full topic

If you could use system.out.println to print the sql statement, then right click the console and hit mark you will be able to select the text in the console. Select the entire SQL statement, and then hit enter. That will copy it to your clipboard.

item.title: Help fixing this error
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

It says your SQL syntax is off.
Meaning you’re trying to submit data to the SQL table, but it’s not in the right format. It’s probably missing some single quotes around some text. I can’t be 100% certain as that doesn’t show the entire sql statement…

If you could use system.out.println to print the sql statement, then right click the console and hit mark you will be able to select the text in the console. Select the entire SQL statement, and then hit enter. That will copy it to your clipboard.
Paste that here so I can see the SQL statement.

Read full topic

item.title: Help fixing this error
item.dc:creator: @Joker678 Joker678
item.description:
@Joker678 wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:2, topic:550996”]You are either missing the Database class, or your compiler isn’t reading the server/mysql/ directory, so it doesn’t see the Database class exists.

How to tell which one is the issue:
Go into src > server > mysql.
If there is a file called “Database.java” then you need to fix the compiler to include the mysql directory. If there is no mysql folder, or no Database.java, then that would be your error. It doesn’t exist.

To add it into your compiler:
Right click the compiler, and hit edit. That will bring it up in Notepad.

Search for *.java.
After the first result, add in:

Make sure there is a space before it, and a space after it.

If the file doesn’t exist:
You have a couple options.

  1. Figure out what was needed in the file, and create it yourself.
  2. Comment out the code that used said file, until you can do option 1.[/quote]
    okay so uhmm i’ve got no errors left but check this out, after someone logouts it doesn’t save account on highscores and this thing appears:
    http://prntscr.com/6rua15

Read full topic

item.title: Help fixing this error
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

You are either missing the Database class, or your compiler isn’t reading the server/mysql/ directory, so it doesn’t see the Database class exists.

How to tell which one is the issue:
Go into src > server > mysql.
If there is a file called “Database.java” then you need to fix the compiler to include the mysql directory. If there is no mysql folder, or no Database.java, then that would be your error. It doesn’t exist.

To add it into your compiler:
Right click the compiler, and hit edit. That will bring it up in Notepad.

Search for *.java.
After the first result, add in:

Make sure there is a space before it, and a space after it.

If the file doesn’t exist:
You have a couple options.

  1. Figure out what was needed in the file, and create it yourself.
  2. Comment out the code that used said file, until you can do option 1.

Read full topic
